verses.text: Better is a poor man who walks in his integrity than one who is perverse in speech and is a fool.
verses.comment: This verse exalts personal integrity over riches gained by dishonesty. Jesus also taught that our true treasure is not earthly but heavenly (Matthew 6:19-21).

verses.text: It is not good for a person to be without knowledge, and whoever hurries with his feet misses the way.
verses.comment: Seeking knowledge and wisdom is painted as a virtue. See James 1:5 for a New Testament encouragement to seek wisdom from God.

verses.text: A person's own foolishness ruins his way, yet his heart rages against the Lord.
verses.comment: Blaming God for the consequences of our own actions is as old as Adam in Genesis 3. Christ calls us to humility and self-examination (Luke 6:41-42).

verses.text: Wealth attracts many friends, but the poor man is deserted by his close companion.
verses.comment: Worldly friendships are often conditional. The faithfulness of Christ, however, is unchanging (Hebrews 13:5).

verses.text: A false witness will not go unpunished, and he who breathes out lies will not escape.
verses.comment: This is echoed in the ninth commandment (Exodus 20:16) and points to God's justice as fulfilled in Christ, the faithful witness (Revelation 1:5).

verses.text: Many seek the favor of a generous man, and everyone is a friend to a man who gives gifts.
verses.comment: Earthly generosity attracts interest but it is true charity, rooted in self-giving love, that lasts eternally (1 Corinthians 13:1-3).

verses.text: All the brothers of the poor man hate him; how much more do his friends go far from him! He pursues them with words, but they are gone.
verses.comment: This highlights the vulnerability of the poor and the importance of caring for those in need—a command reinforced by Jesus in Matthew 25:40.

verses.text: He who gets wisdom loves his own soul; he who keeps understanding will find good.
verses.comment: Wisdom is repeatedly equated with life and blessing. Christ Himself is the incarnate wisdom of God (1 Corinthians 1:24).

verses.text: A false witness will not go unpunished, and he who lies will perish.
verses.comment: Repetition emphasizes the seriousness of false testimony—echoing Jesus’ teaching about truthfulness (Matthew 5:37).

verses.text: It is not fitting for a fool to live in luxury, much less for a slave to rule over princes.
verses.comment: This proverb observes the ordering of society; when order is reversed, disorder results. The New Testament sees Christ elevate the humble (Luke 1:52).

verses.text: A person's insight makes him slow to anger, and it is his glory to overlook an offense.
verses.comment: Patience and forgiveness reflect the character of God, as seen supremely in Jesus' example (Ephesians 4:32).

verses.text: The king's wrath is like the roar of a lion, but his favor is like dew on the grass.
verses.comment: Earthly kings reflect aspects of divine authority and mercy. Jesus is the true King who holds both justice and compassion (John 18:37).

verses.text: A foolish son is a ruin to his father, and the quarrels of a wife are a continual dripping.
verses.comment: The proverb encourages harmony within the family, a major theme throughout both Testaments (Ephesians 5:22-33).

verses.text: House and wealth are inherited from fathers, but a prudent wife is from the Lord.
verses.comment: Wisdom regards a godly spouse as a divine gift. Paul also teaches the blessing of a holy marriage in 1 Corinthians 7.

verses.text: Laziness brings deep sleep, and an idle person will suffer hunger.
verses.comment: Diligence is praised in Proverbs and in Paul’s teaching (2 Thessalonians 3:10-12), reinforcing the spiritual call to fruitful labor.

verses.text: He who keeps the commandment preserves his life; he who despises his ways will die.
verses.comment: Obedience to God’s commands brings life (Deuteronomy 30:16-20). Following Christ, who fulfilled the Law, is the way to eternal life (John 14:15-21).

verses.text: He who is kind to the poor lends to the Lord, and He will repay him for his deed.
verses.comment: Charity is not just social justice but is seen as a direct gift to God (see Matthew 25:40). Acts of mercy are treasured in heaven.

verses.text: Discipline your son while there is hope, and do not desire to cause his death.
verses.comment: Correction rooted in love is necessary for growth; God disciplines His children for their good (Hebrews 12:6-11).

verses.text: A man of great anger will bear the penalty, for if you deliver him, you will only have to do it again.
verses.comment: Unrestrained anger leads to repeated folly. The New Testament urges repeated forgiveness (Matthew 18:22) but also calls for true repentance.

verses.text: Listen to advice and accept instruction, that you may gain wisdom in the future.
verses.comment: Openness to instruction is praised; Christ calls His disciples to be teachable (Matthew 11:29).

verses.text: Many are the plans in a person's heart, but it is the Lord's purpose that will stand.
verses.comment: This proclaims God's sovereignty over human affairs, reflected also in Romans 8:28 and Ephesians 1:11.

verses.text: What is desirable in a person is steadfast love, and a poor man is better than a liar.
verses.comment: Steadfast love (hesed) is a central biblical value. Christ is the embodiment of this love (John 15:13).

verses.text: The fear of the Lord leads to life, and whoever has it rests satisfied; he will not be visited by harm.
verses.comment: Reverence for God brings spiritual security. Christ’s perfect fear of the Lord led Him through suffering to resurrection life (Hebrews 5:7).

verses.text: The sluggard buries his hand in the dish, but will not even bring it back to his mouth.
verses.comment: Comical exaggeration displays the consequence of laziness. The call is to action and cooperation with God’s grace (Philippians 2:12-13).

verses.text: Strike a scoffer, and the simple will become prudent; reprove one who has understanding, and he will gain knowledge.
verses.comment: Correction for the wise produces fruit, and discipline serves as a witness to others, aligning with Jesus’ method of teaching (Matthew 13:10-13).

verses.text: He who does violence to his father and chases away his mother is a son who brings shame and disgrace.
verses.comment: This sharp condemnation supports the Fifth Commandment (Exodus 20:12) and Jesus’ rebuke of those who dishonor parents (Mark 7:9-13).

verses.text: Cease listening, my son, to instruction, and you will stray from the words of knowledge.
verses.comment: Continual learning is necessary for spiritual growth. The Church is called to be ‘always reforming’ by returning to apostolic teaching (Acts 2:42).

verses.text: A worthless witness mocks justice, and the mouth of the wicked devours iniquity.
verses.comment: God's justice is not mocked; false witness is condemned throughout Scripture (see also Matthew 26:59-60, Jesus' trial).

verses.text: Judgments are prepared for scoffers, and beatings for the backs of fools.
verses.comment: Divine discipline is used as a tool for correction. God’s justice and mercy are perfectly united in Christ (Romans 2:4-8).
